Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: What CS research can look like and more in-depth knowledge about the specific field that my project was on
I learned how to construct a neural network to address an issue in NLP.

Obviously there was domain-specific knowledge I learned in order to work on the project, but on top of that the biggest things were:
1. Taking initiative in joining or proposing a project (in my case joining a project)
2. Getting feedback, dealing with slip-ups or failures in the development process
3. Time management and setting realistic goals for what can be done by the deadline

This course gave me the opportunity to explore my interest in the intersection of legal and ethical questions surrounding computer science. I got to research a topic of interest and discuss my ideas with my adviser, who also found my topic and my research to be of interest.
It was a good way to get an in depth knowledge on a very specific topic.
Independent research
The language Coq, how to formally and mathematically prove things in code. I also learned a lot about the ethereum system, the compiler compcert, and how to build my own verified compiler.
Doing a senior project was a great way to explore a field of computer science I was interested in and experience the world of research.

This course is going to depend alot of who your advisor is and what your project is. You will learn a lot about managing a large project over the course of the semester. While you will learn how to do work on your own, meeting with your advisor is super important! Make sure to set up weekly meetings with your advisor to keep on track!

Since I had the chance to work on a bigger project from start to finish, I was able to practice the process of research, design, implement, experiment, and iterate. I'm proud of the work I did and have a much better understanding of reinforcement learning now.

My senior project has been a great learning experience. I learned about technologies I used to build my project such as React, Node.js, MongoDB, HTML, and CSS. I learned how to write scalable and maintainable code to make debugging easier when I'm fixing bug or building new features. I also learned how to build a solid project architecture and develop a product from scratch all the way to deployment.
I learned how to implement Q-learning on a robotic platform for human-robot collaboration. I improved my Python and ROS (robot operating system) skills
Make sure you find and read the CPSC 490 website, because you'll never get any notification about what you're supposed to be doing.
Allows exploration of personal interests. Interaction with advisor varies by advisor, thus choose one that won't be too busy for you.

While I do appreciate the federalist structure of the course, I think some overarching requirements/guidelines would be helpful for both parties (requiring professors to meet with students a certain amount of times a month, etc).
There should be more guidelines at the end on how to submit that are more clear.

I quite enjoyed the flexibility of this course - I got to study a topic of pertinence to current events. The course could use a little more structure - from my understanding, there were no clear intermediate deadlines, and there were other people in the course who did not know when their projects were due.
The 490 page is very clear about the requirements, other than that it is up to each student and their advisor.
Its good as is.
Not enough structure, grading based on advisor so expectations vary a lot.
Good course.
Great opportunity for students to do either academic research or an applied project.

Strengths: Really great advisor and project
Weakness: There is little instruction on the final expectations for the project/report, and more guidance would have helped me pace my research throughout the semester.

This course is very loosely structured, but it's definitely a class that you can get alot out of if you choose to. You can also get very little out of it, so it depends on how you approach your project!
Strengths: great flexibility to design a project suited to your interests. I definitely recommend this route because it makes the work inherently more interesting.
I mean, it's mandatory for CS majors, so yeah, I guess.
You have to take it.

Very important to be smart about TIMING. Read all of the information about the department requirements at http://dus.cs.yale.edu/490.html EARLY to know what is expected of you. Consult with your adviser to set realistic goals for what you can get done over the term given your schedule. And have fun with it. The more work you have put into it over the term, the prouder you will feel of the result when at the end.
Sure.

If you are a computer science major, you will have to take this course. For the majors who will end up taking this course, it is easier to pick an adviser and a project if you already have some idea of what you want to do with CS.

I highly recommend 490. I took it in my last semester and regret not taking it earlier. For anyone interested in research, it is a great way to get credit for learning about and working on a very specific interest. I recommend meeting with your advisor weekly if possible to give yourself deadlines that force you to accomplish intermediary goals throughout the semester.
Yes, it is required for the CS major.
Take it to graduate as a CS major. It's fun to take on a research project. Try to actually do something new that is a personal challenge.
It's required, so yes. But it's also a great time. Would recommend doing it in the fall of senior year.
It's a good opportunity for some, and can be hard for others. It's very project/advisor dependent.
